item.title: Cosine Law
item.description: The cosine law is as follows: $sa^2=b^2+c^2-2bc(cosA)$e . The cosine law can be used to find a side length from the two other sides and the angle between them. The proof is as follows: Assume a triangle $s\triangle ABC$e , where, $sh$e is a line from $sB$e to $sD$e (which is a point on $s\overline{AC}$e ) where, $s\angle BDC=\angle BDA=90^{\circ}$e . From the cosine ratio: $scosC=\frac{CD}{a}$e , or $sCS=acosC$e $sDA=b-acosC$e $sBD=asinC$e Using the pythegorean theorem, $sc^2=(BD)^2+(DA)^2$e , or $sc^2=(asinC)^2+(b-acosC)^2$e , or $sc^2=a^2+b^2-2abcosC$e .

item.title: Sine Law
item.description: The sine law is as follows: $s\frac{a}{\sin{A}} \,=\, \frac{b}{\sin{B}} \,=\, \frac{c}{\sin{C}} \,=\, 2R$e , where $sa$e , $sb$e , and $sc$e , are the lengths of the sides of the triangle, and $s\alpha$e , $s\beta$e , and $s\gamma$e , are the opposite angles of the sides, and $sR$e is the radius of the triangle’s circumcircle. The sine law can be used to find the other sides of an acute triangle when two angles and a side are given.

item.title: True Bearings
item.description: True bearings are written as angle°T, and are the same as turnign angle° clockwise from north.
